name: Passiflora_caparaoensis
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Alto Caparaó, Parque Nacional do Caparaó, Tronqueira, 2000 m
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.545.2.3 Etymology: The specific epithet refers to the type locality, the region of Caparaó (between Minas Gerais and Espírito Santo states), and that gives the name to Caparaó National Park.

name: Passiflora_carajasensis
locality: Parauapebas, Serra dos Carajás, urban nucleus of Vale

name: Passiflora_cearaensis
publication: Contr. Jard. Bot. Rio de Janeiro
reference: Contr. Jard. Bot. Rio de Janeiro 4: 92, tab. 16. 1907

name: Passiflora_coelestis
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.516.2.2 The specific epithet refers to Faxinal do Céu, the place where the plant was found, with 'Céu' meaning 'heaven' in Portuguese.

name: Passiflora_ita
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);
locality: Minas Gerais, Conselheiro Pena, Serra do Padre Ângelo, Pico do Padre Ângelo, 1480 m
remarks: doi:10.3372/wi.51.51305 The specific epithet is a noun in apposition, originating in the noun itá of the Tupi-Guarani language, meaning 'rock' (Carvalho 1987). The epithet alludes to the rupicolous habit of the species, growing among and over rocks.

name: Passiflora_jorgeana
locality: Barreiras, estrada de terra de acesso à Cachoeira do Acaba-Vidas, 724 m
remarks: doi:10.3417/2020630 Named in memory of Jorge Mário Pires, the first author’s father and her eternal personal and professional inspiration. Additionally, 'Jorge' comes from the Greek, meaning 'one who works on the land', which is appropriate for a Passiflora that survives in the very narrow Cerrado from Barreiras, surrounded by extensive crops.

name: Passiflora_mediterrana
reference: Fl. Flumin. Icon. 9: t. 72. 1831 [1827 publ. 29 Oct 1831]

name: Passiflora_purii
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.1590/1677-941X-ABB-2022-0122 Etymology: the specific epithet honours the Puri ethnicity, which, before the arrival of the Portuguese, inhabited the regions of SM located in the basins of the Paraíba do Sul River and the upper Rio Doce.

name: Passiflora_timboensis
collectorTeam: Amorim, Jardim, Ferreira, Perdiz, Paixão & Gomes
locality: Mun. Amargosa, Serra do Timbó, com acesso pelo Morro Pelado
